prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer within a proposed multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent individuals who remain constant across all layers, while the weighted connections indicate social interactions that could potentially lead to infection based on the probability value assigned to each edge (ranging from 0 to 1). The initial layer depicts interactions within households, with various groups of different sizes that are internally connected but remain isolated from external connections. These groups mirror the distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2011, considering probabilities of family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country needs to engage in some form of work or economic activity, which involves interacting with others. This makes work a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model work activity, we suggest incorporating a generic layer to link individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of the total population in the case of Argentina. Given the diverse array of jobs and companies, establishing a connection rule that accurately mirrors the real world can be challenging. In our approach, we consider a typical scenario where random groups of varying sizes (ranging from 5 to 30) are internally connected, resembling the structure of households. This is illustrated in Figure 2(b) for a sample size of 100. Although nodes within a group are fully connected, the spread of the virus is influenced by the strength of these connections, as detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is a crucial aspect of urban life in many cities, serving as a potential hub for viral transmission due to high population density and constant movement. The third layer in our model represents these collective transport systems frequented by individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, public transport usage varies based on city size, with approximately 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities, averaging around 1.2 hours per day. To account for these differences, we randomly select 50% of the population to participate in the "transports" layer, forming groups of different sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals, each fully connected within the group.

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25
author: enrique
pre_context: In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, and colleagues explore the impact of various interventions on the overall spread of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation starts with a social network with its original infection probabilities, with the first infection occurring at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree. The infection then spreads in daily iterations over 300 days. The study considers an optimistic scenario in which individuals are aware of the virus from the outset, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: . The activities remaining on these layers are services that must continue despite the quarantine, such as essential services and activities with increased precautions. In this scenario, we first examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for 4 β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths, analyzed up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to faster spread of the disease and increased cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends more quickly due to natural immunity from recovered individuals. Comparing the model's outputs to real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18 (first 83 days), using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit. This reflects the current situation where people are taking precautions, such as wearing masks. The model shows overall similarity with the real data, with the differences in diagnosed cases possibly attributed to increased testing and fluctuating isolation levels. The model's daily death toll averages higher than official numbers, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing. This underscores the need for further analysis and understanding of the epidemic's progression.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study by eiva et al. (2021), the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy rates. The study began with a social network model, starting with the original infection probabilities and spreading from a node with a degree closest to the network average. In an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, an initial infection probability of β < 1 was used to mimic social distancing practices and other precautions. The researchers found that this initial value of β produced results that closely mirrored the Argentine pandemic. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was introduced, reducing contacts in various layers of society. The researchers observed how varying the β parameter affected the trajectory of the epidemic, with higher infection rates leading to faster spread but also faster termination due to natural immunity. The study provides valuable insights into the dynamics of epidemics and the effectiveness of different intervention strategies.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The recent increase in diagnosed cases in Argentina over the past ten days may be due to an increase in testing or a decrease in isolation levels (which have been consistently below 50% for most days over the past month) [43]. We assumed a fixed isolation level similar to what was observed in the early days after the government decrees in Argentina, but data from the same source indicates that these levels are fluctuating. Therefore, it is possible that the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than those reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section). In terms of daily death toll, the average number in our model is higher than the official figures, which is to be expected due to potential underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. To further illustrate this point, we compared the number of deaths in Argentina from January 1 to April 30 between 2019 and 2020, revealing an increasing trend after February 26, the date of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina. This suggests that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than what is officially reported.

Looking ahead, we are considering four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26) once the initial epidemic phase has passed: a) Maintain current isolation levels and take no further action; b) Cease isolation and return to normal activities with initial networking layers and weights; c) Resume only work activities while restoring the initial layer probabilities; or d) Increase isolation by halting all remaining work and transport activities.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 7 from the study conducted by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) shows the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three different scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Maintaining current isolation measures (no schools or religious gatherings, limited work and transport), (b) Ending isolation (resuming normal school, religion, work, and transport activities), or (c) Increasing isolation (shutting down work and public transport). The availability of testing is constrained, either due to a limited number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus surpassing testing capacity. It was assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days from the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented which included the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transportation continued at a reduced capacity of 30%, achieved by further reducing the beta term. Following 90 days from the first case, various actions were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, lifting isolation and resuming all activities at 100%, or only resuming work activities. The results indicate that maintaining current isolation levels will result in prolonged spread, with a projected peak around June 5, averaging 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, it is estimated there will be 946,830 diagnosed cases (with up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, however, efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistical management of patients could help maintain control. It is important to note that the assumption of "maintaining isolation" in this context refers to social isolation above 50%, as observed at the start of the Argentine quarantine. Currently, social isolation levels in Argentina are consistently at 12%.

This model is applied in Scenarios 1 and 3 to analyze the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask wearing. The formula for the infection rate, taking into account gradual noncompliance with universal masking, is adjusted from Equation (9) to Equation (10). As people start to exhibit noncompliance due to pandemic fatigue and complacency, the infection rate represented by βnc is expected to slightly increase. Unlike the sudden decrease in infection rate observed when compulsory mask wearing is enforced, noncompliance will occur gradually, leading to a smoother transition from βc to βnc. Despite some noncompliance, the infection rate βnc is anticipated to be lower than βs due to increased awareness of the seriousness of the situation, leading to a more cautious approach compared to pre-pandemic times.

prior_outline: Time-Based Model for Compulsory Mask Wearing
author: chunwei
pre_context: In the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health in 2021, a modified logistic function is used to model the transition from infection rates before and after the enforcement of compulsory masking. The function includes parameters such as βs and βc, with βs representing the infection rate before enforcement and βc representing the infection rate after full compliance of masking. The model also considers the number of days after the first case when masking wearing is enforced, denoted as t0. This modified logistic function is applied in both Scenarios 1 and 3. To account for gradual noncompliance with universal masking, Equation (9) is further modified to include additional terms. As individuals begin to exhibit noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue, the infection rate represented by βnc increases slightly over time. Compared to the immediate quenching effect of compulsory masking enforcement, the gradual increase in noncompliance results in a slower change in infection rates. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and
post_context: , taken in context to Malaysia's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. It is anticipated that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs because despite some complacency and fatigue, there is now a heightened awareness of the seriousness of the situation. The general population is expected to be more cautious compared to before the pandemic.

The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants κ1 and κ2, where κ1 > κ2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. In the study's results and discussion, the impact of delaying the enforcement of mask wearing was analyzed using SEIR models under three scenarios. It was found that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days taken to reach this maximum value. This is illustrated by a rightward shift of the peak value of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maximum before decreasing, as predicted by compartmental models. This global maximum is known as the Maximum Infected Value. For instance, in the scenario where mask wearing was enforced on the day the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Malaysia, there was a significant impact on the trajectory of the infection curve.

6. Results and Discussion 6.1. Impact of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing: By applying SEIR models to the scenarios described, different values of mask enforcement delays were simulated to determine the Maximum Infected Values. In the most basic scenario of complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, the effects of enforcing masks on the day of the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia, after 50 days, after 100 days, and not enforced at all were analyzed. Results show that early enforcement of mask wearing reduces the Maximum Infected Value and prolongs the time to reach it. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right and the maximum value of infections decreases. After reaching a global maximum, the number of infections decreases according to the compartmental model. For example, with no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is around 10.453% on day 291 after the first case was detected, while a 50-day delay shows a different outcome.

When we apply the SEIR models to the three scenarios discussed earlier, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different days: (a) when the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Indonesia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all. Early enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also delays the peak of infected cases. The maximum infected value decreases as we move from left to right on the curve. The peak of infected cases occurs at a global maximum before tapering off, as expected from compartmental models.

For instance, when mask enforcement is immediate (a), the maximum infected value is about 10.453% and the peak occurs on day 291 after the first case was detected. With a 50-day delay (b), the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479% and the peak occurs on day 195. With a 100-day delay (c), the maximum infected value significantly increases to approximately 27.474% and the peak occurs much earlier, on day 103. This is similar to the scenario where no public masking is enforced (d), where the maximum infected value is also high.

text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: This version of the medRxiv preprint, posted on April 17, 2020, discusses an agent-based epidemic model called REINA for COVID-19. The copyright holder, the author/funder, has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study aims to identify effective policies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, as countries have implemented varying strategies.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments and interventions such as physical isolation, testing, tracing, and controlling the number of cases entering the area. It has open-source code and can be run online. Results show various strategies to manage hospital capacity by implementing mobility restrictions, aggressive testing, tracing, and isolating coronavirus positive patients and their contacts. The model begins on 2020-02-18 and follows the actual situation until 2020-04-06 before diverging. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow the spread of the epidemic. The model uses the demographics of the Helsinki University Hospital region with a population of 1.6 million. Please note that this research has not undergone peer review and should not guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The version of this preprint was posted on April 17, 2020 and can be found at doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498. The diagram in Figure 1 depicts the coronavirus agent model, illustrating different states of the agents, transitions between states, infection pathways, and population subgroups under various levels of social isolation. The model includes an "incubating" state for individuals who have the virus but do not yet show symptoms and explicitly divides the "infectious" state into multiple sub-states. The healthcare system parameters considered in the model include hospital beds, intensive care beds, testing mode, number of tests performed per day, and length of testing queues.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records all contacts made by infected individuals, allowing for analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Estimating the Risk of Transmission of the 2019-nCoV and its Implications for Public Health Interventions - This article by Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu, explores the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV and its potential impact on public health interventions. The study was conducted by researchers from the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China, and the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of the travel restrictions imposed by Wuhan on infections in Beijing is comparable to a 100-thousand-fold increase in quarantine measures. It is vital to evaluate the effectiveness of the costly and resource-intensive measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling the spread of 2019-nCoV, as well as determining how long they should be in place. Under the strictest measures, it is projected that the outbreak will peak within two weeks (since January 23, 2020) with a significantly lower peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing exposed individuals from entering Beijing) could lead to a 91.14% decrease in infected individuals in Beijing within seven days compared to not having such restrictions. This underscores the importance of measures such as quarantine, isolation, and travel restrictions in managing and controlling the spread of the coronavirus.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
To estimate the basic reproduction number (Rc) for 2019-nCoV in Xian, China, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano [23]. The formula used for estimation is provided as: L(Rc, p|N) = Π exp(-φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1) , where φt = Rc ΣpjNt- j, k is the maximum value of the serial interval (set as k = 6), and Γ(x) is the gamma function.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Respiratory infections exhibit varying intensity and transmission patterns due to disparities in vulnerable populations and risk factors, influencing the pathogen's spatial diffusion. Unequal healthcare system capacities also play a significant role in determining disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately impacted regions in the Northeastern United States, with higher case and death rates reported. The reasons behind these regional disparities remain unclear.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio in relation to healthcare capacity distribution. 

In order to achieve this, we constructed a spatial mathematical model to replicate the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 within the state. This model includes geographical connectivity information at the county level and follows the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) framework. Building on research linking air hubs and main roads to COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality, the model stratifies counties into four spatial risk groups based on their connectivity index. The dynamics of disease transmission and infection progression within each group are captured through various epidemiological compartments. Susceptible individuals in each group face differing rates of exposure to infection, which are influenced by group-specific factors and time.

pre_context: Counties in Ohio with higher air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of COVID-19 infections compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. This geographical disparity in infection severity was not just due to population distribution but also to factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties with high population density and airports that receive millions of passengers annually. The influx of travelers in these counties can lead to a higher transmission rate of the virus locally, accelerating the spread of infection in these areas. (Organization, 2020; Warren et al., 2010).In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio  included  in  Group  4. Although  these  less  densely  populated counties  are  home  of  only  11%  of  the  total  population  in  Ohio,  the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: .On the other hand, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural counties, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 residents. Despite these disparities in healthcare capacity, our analysis suggests that lower transmission rates in these remote counties prevented critical care saturation. If the state's interventions remained in place after early May, only 27% of maximum critical care capacity would be used, excluding the 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. However, if interventions were eased by 50%, approximately 61% of maximum capacity would be reached statewide within eight weeks. Areas with higher disease transmission (Group 1) would hit capacity faster, while counties in Group 4 experienced slower spread and less strain on healthcare resources.

pre_context: D.F. Cuadros and colleagues examined the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using adjusted models and found that counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to those in Group 1. This reduces the risk of critical care saturation in Group 4 counties, with only 55% of their maximum capacity expected to be reached eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. However, some counties in Group 4, such as Adams, Champaign, and Seneca, may reach over 60% of their critical care capacity. Strategies to strengthen critical care response in these low connected counties, along with local air hub counties, have been identified as high priority in Ohio's fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, localized outbreaks have the potential to significantly impact critical care capacity in the areas where they occur and can contribute to the spread of the disease. The SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was developed using data exclusively from Ohio. The COVID-19 pandemic consists of various sub-epidemics with varying intensities, even within the same country, as evidenced by outbreaks at different times and in different locations in the U.S. Each state has implemented different control measures at different times, leading to differences in the disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the model's performance using data from various locations. Despite its limitations, this study presents one of the initial spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, illustrating spatial discrepancies in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, cumulative hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite apparently similar circumstances, different US states and national governments implemented drastically different responses to the pandemic. Utilizing simulation-based epidemic models could potentially help resolve this uncertainty and aid in making informed decisions. These models allow for predictions tailored to the unique circumstances of various entities, such as universities, cities, states, or nations. By testing different interventions virtually and observing the projected outcomes, the hope is to identify the most effective course of action. However, it is important to note that epidemic models only provide an approximation of reality and are subject to uncertainties in input parameters, as well as the potential for exponential growth, which can impact accuracy. Despite criticisms for producing inaccurate point estimates, simulation models can still assist in making informed decisions, as demonstrated through a case study of COVID-19 interventions implemented at Cornell University. Furthermore, a modeling framework is introduced that can potentially support decision-making at other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work informed the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for in-person instruction in fall 2020 and helped design a crucial asymptomatic screening program. Following our modeling recommendations, 75% of students returned to campus for the 2020–2021 school year under this program. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing with less-sensitive AN sampling, based on our modeling that comfort led to better test compliance. Cornell implemented a robust surveillance program with support for large-scale sample collection and a new testing lab, in partnership with a local health care provider. Our modeling recommendations prompted updates to the strategy for the following semesters, including more frequent testing for certain groups and adjustments for the Delta variant and vaccination status. Despite these challenges, the number of infections among students and staff remained low compared to schools offering only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying parameters that can control epidemics successfully.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior probability distribution was established for parameters, consisting of independent normal distributions for each parameter. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were determined so that the resulting 95% Bayesian credible interval aligned with plausible ranges for each parameter. The decision to use a multivariate normal distribution as a prior was influenced by both modeling and tractability concerns. The unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours was necessary for the subsequent analysis. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this Bayesian prior, with values truncated as needed to ensure feasibility. Simulations were then run for each set, resulting in a prior distribution over infections that accounted for parameter uncertainty. While 2×/wk testing was generally effective for infection control, large outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To explore the impact of interventions like testing on robustness in the face of parameter uncertainty, a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with varying levels of pessimism regarding infection numbers was developed.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.We refer to the former as "pessimistic (residential)" in graphs to differentiate it from a scenario pessimistic about a separate outcome in Results D. This scenario involves setting each parameter to the middle of its range, known as the nominal scenario. Compared to the nominal scenario, the pessimistic scenario significantly increases the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate while decreasing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness, leading to a greater effect on infections. The assumption of linearity when creating these scenarios was found to have little impact on the level of pessimism present. Simulated infections using bi-weekly testing at different levels of pessimism showed that this level of testing generally kept infections below 1,000, although some parameter configurations exceeded this threshold. Additional testing could reduce this risk, with high test frequencies keeping infections low even at high levels of pessimism. Public reports and presentations to the Cornell Faculty Senate included figures and scenarios similar to those discussed here.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, we conducted a Bayesian analysis to investigate the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate on COVID-19 transmission. We adjusted our model to reflect the increased transmission rates associated with the Delta variant by a factor of 2.5. Additionally, we included parameters representing the effectiveness of vaccines in preventing transmission and infection susceptibility. Most of the Cornell student population was vaccinated, exceeding 95% once international students were also immunized. Changes in social distancing measures, prevalence rates, contact tracing procedures, and quarantine requirements for vaccinated individuals introduced uncertainty into our model. We applied a joint prior to these parameters, conducted simulations for each parameter set, and updated our prior to a posterior distribution. The results, shown in Fig. 6A, demonstrate uncertainty in individual parameters but more confidence in their combined effect.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.(B) The study estimated the median cumulative infections throughout the semester for student vaccination levels of 50%, 75%, and 100%, in relation to the average number of tests per student per week. This analysis considered a variety of Pareto-optimal testing strategies.

pre_context: It is estimated that by the end of 2021, approximately 680,000 people in Ontario will have been infected with COVID-19, with half of them showing no symptoms. The highest increase in infections occurred in December 2021 and March 2021, corresponding to peaks in new case counts. By the end of the year, 71% of the population would have received at least one dose of the vaccine, and 57% would be fully vaccinated. Around 11,000 people would have died from COVID-19 by the end of the year, with varying percentages from the wild type, Alpha, and Delta variants. These predicted numbers align closely with the reported data in Ontario. The population dynamics are illustrated in the figures provided. The susceptible population significantly decreases after December 2021 due to the vaccine rollout. By June 2021, only 37% of the population are susceptible, with most having received at least one vaccine dose. The number of active infections peaks in late 2021 and then again in late spring, driven by the wild type and Alpha variants. The Alpha variant peak diminishes as vaccination efforts progress. The infections are split evenly between symptomatic and asymptomatic cases, with the majority of cases in unvaccinated individuals. The recovered population also increases throughout the year, reaching 7% of the total population by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. This includes the number of new infections, cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, population vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths. Small fluctuations in these parameters can lead to significant differences in infection and mortality rates, as demonstrated in Fig. 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19 plays a crucial role in determining the number of infected individuals who can potentially spread the virus. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 were adjusted by 5%, leading to significant impacts on model predictions for NPIs, which are modeled by scaling βW directly (Fig. 4). The rate of vaccination also plays a role in influencing the spread of the disease, although to a lesser extent. On the other hand, dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have smaller effects. Due to the potential variability of dosing intervals within the population and the lack of precise characterization of vaccine escape rates, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The findings related to vaccination suggest that effective deployment of the vaccine (represented by ω1) is crucial in fighting a pandemic, indicating that success can still be achieved with a less-than-ideal vaccine that has a higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Given that changes in ω1 have a greater impact on predicted infections and deaths compared to changes in ω2, if vaccine availability is limited, prioritizing the first dose by extending the dosing interval may be a prudent strategy, similar to the approach taken in Canada. author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the sensitivity of model predictions for total infections and deaths to increases in model parameter values over a two-year simulation that considers the dynamics of variants of concern (VOCs). The parameters are individually varied for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. Changes in the number of infections and deaths are then calculated for each variant. Parameters examined include virus infectivity, rate of infection of individuals recovered from a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections, and other factors related to infection and immunity. The baseline model assumes a distribution of Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines, with a higher percentage of Pfizer vaccines in Ontario compared to the UK. It is noted that the Pfizer vaccine provides warm stronger protection against all COVID variants, especially Delta, after one or two doses, compared in contrast to the AstraZeneca vaccine. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the Beginning of 2022, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day. The projected number of Delta infections and deaths for 2022 is expected to be higher than previously estimated, with estimates at 62,000 and 882, respectively, compared to the earlier predictions of 39,000 and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province is lower, with only 67% of the population receiving at least one dose by September 1, 2022, compared to the initial 74%, the total number of Delta infections and deaths is expected to rise by 75% by March 2022. Ontario began reopening in mid-June 2022, with in-person classes set to resume in September. While the baseline model assumes that the NPI will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%, considering a scenario with less stringent NPI starting in fall 2022 is necessary due to factors such as pandemic fatigue and potential outbreaks in schools. This involves an increase in λ from its baseline value of 0.4 (Scientific Reports | (2022) 12:2114 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-022-06159-x).

author: chunwei
pre_context: Research on disease modelling has been based on previous studies of the SARS outbreak. It was observed that the SARS outbreak had a large basic reproduction number within hospitals and a smaller number in the general community, resulting in a moderate overall number. The current 2019 n-Cov situation appears to have similarities with the SARS outbreak, with Wuhan serving as the epicenter and the entire country being affected due to travel before the outbreak was contained. The situation is rapidly changing in Wuhan, Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations indicate that the control of the outbreak depends on interventions implemented in the field and resources provided to healthcare workers and patients. Factors such as speed of diagnoses and hospitalization of confirmed cases will influence the size and timing of the outbreak peak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately forecasting the trend of an epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge of how to implement and utilize available resources to support public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We appreciate the support from various organizations such as the Tianyuan Mathematical Center and the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences. References include studies on the Novel Wuhan coronavirus and modeling strategies for controlling outbreaks.

post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the importance of localized variability in stratification, shedding light on the variations in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, accurately simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world may require a dynamic parameterization of meltwater settling depth. In this paper, we discuss potential developments in this area and identify remaining challenges. KEYWORDS: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change 

Introduction

One of the notable shortcomings of the global coupled climate models included in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5) has been their inability to accurately capture observed Southern Ocean climate trends such as surface cooling, surface freshening, and sea ice expansion. The increase in the Antarctic meltwater anomaly over recent years may have contributed to these trends. By incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models, we may be able to better align model simulations with observed trends. Recent studies suggest that considering Antarctic glacial meltwater could help bridge the gap between observations and simulations.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The results of various simulations suggest that failing to adhere to social distancing and hygiene practices can have serious consequences for the human population. The model demonstrates that quarantining contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic under different intervention scenarios, providing valuable insights into effective measures to reduce the risk of the epidemic. Previous research has also utilized mathematical modeling to estimate transmission rates during outbreaks of similar viruses like MERS-CoV.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is represented as P(t), while the human population is denoted as N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has shown that COVID-19 can spread through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals who are asymptomatic (IA(t)) or symptomatic (IS(t)) can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment. Since the pathogen can survive in the environment for days, susceptible individuals in close proximity may be exposed, especially early in the outbreak. As the disease spreads, susceptible individuals transition to the exposed population (E(t)), which may then progress to either asymptomatic or symptomatic infectious populations. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interactions at time t. Most infectious individuals recover and move to the recovered population (R(t)). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and pathogens is shown in Figure 1, with the parameters detailed in Table 1. The model leads to a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as shown in the SEIR-P model in Figure 1.

In our model, we suggest new infections occur as β2S(IA+IS) in the form of 1+α2(IA+IS), where α1 and α2 represent the proportions of interaction with susceptible individuals getting infected from the environment and infectious individuals, respectively. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR‑P model are derived by solving equations when the left side equals zero. The disease-free equilibrium point occurs when IA = IS = P = 0, resulting in E = 0 and R = 0 as well. The basic reproduction number, R0, determines the average secondary infections caused by an individual in a fully susceptible population, indicating the potential spread of infection. Using the next generation matrix approach, R0 is calculated as part of the model.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, if the epidemic is not mitigated, the number of infected individuals will increase rapidly, exceeding the capacity of hospital beds, which is set at 8000. Among the infected population, it is estimated that 30% exhibit mild or no symptoms. The simulation study utilizes model parameters outlined in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are believed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commuting. This results in a surge of cases, as shown in Figures 2a and 2b, between 10 and 35 days. The model incorporates constants α1 and α2, representing the frequency of acquiring the virus from the environment or infected individuals. When α1 = 0.05, the risk of infection from the environment is high, leading to an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, the risk of infection from an infected individual is higher. By the 23rd day, the number of susceptible individuals diminishes when α2 = 0.05, as many are rapidly infected. Subsequently, the number of new infections decreases from the 25th day onwards, particularly when compared to settings with different values of α1 and α2. The model underscores the importance of implementing control measures like social distancing to mitigate the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The data in Table 1 illustrates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 through various contacts such as households, workplaces, schools, foodstuffs, and during commuting. This results in a surge of the virus in settings like workplaces, schools, foodstuffs, and public transport, ultimately leading to a rise in confirmed coronavirus cases within 10 to 35 days, as shown in Fig. 2a. In this model, the constants α1 and α2 represent the frequency with which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. Fig. 2 demonstrates that when α1 = 0.05, the risk of infection from a contaminated environment is higher than from an infected individual, causing an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. On the other hand, when α2 = 0.05, indicating a higher likelihood of infection from an individual than from a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals diminishes by the 23rd day as a result of rapid infection spread, as shown in Fig. 2c. Further details can be found in Fig. 2d-f within the first 20 days of the model.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention through serology using a protective immunity shield Table 1 | Summary of policy Shielding Transmission Background Susceptible Infectious Recovered Recovery Virus: negative Antibodies: negative Virus: positive Antibodies: positive/negative Virus: negative Antibodies: positiveb Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.Although uncertainties persist regarding the duration and efficacy of immunity, the strategic identification and mobilization of recovered individuals offer a means to decrease transmission for the greater good. Undertaking extensive serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive measures to bring an end to the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, potentially resulting in a final outbreak affecting less than 25% of the population compared to an expected 90% without intervention. Our core shielding model serves as a foundation for applying this strategy to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative advantages of shielding. However, further refinements, such as detailed mixing and substitution models, could enhance this approach in specific contexts, such as spatially explicit areas or within networks. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying the analysis by excluding factors like births and other causes of death. We define a population with susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic, symptomatic, and recovered individuals, operating under a 'business as usual' scenario where movement is unconstrained. A proportion of symptomatic cases will necessitate hospitalization, further divided into subacute and critical cases requiring intensive care unit intervention. We assume a significant portion of critical cases will result in fatalities. Age-specific risks of hospitalization and critical cases are derived from prior studies modeling potential scenarios in the UK and US. Our comprehensive model incorporating shield immunity departs from traditional SIR models with social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mitigation and suppression are currently the main strategies for combating the spread of COVID-19, but questions about long-term effectiveness and exit strategies have arisen. In addition to these approaches, we have introduced a 'shield immunity' model that utilizes serological tests to identify and utilize individuals who have recovered from the virus and developed protective antibodies. Serological testing is crucial for identifying those who are immune to SARS-CoV-2 in the short term. Our analysis has shown significant decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are involved in interventions, reducing the risk of transmission. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, integrating the behavior of seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated the effectiveness of 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as potential alternative mechanisms for substituting interactions. In a flexible shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have enhanced time-varying interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while maintaining the total contact rate the same as the baseline. A fixed shielding mechanism involves recovered individuals having enhanced time-fixed interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate, while keeping the total contact rate the same as the baseline. Extended Data Fig. 1 demonstrates that shielding is effective in these alternative scenarios, and may even be more effective. For instance, in a scenario of fixed shielding with α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

post_context: and other measures were implemented.The findings in Figure 3 illustrate how different levels of shielding interventions can impact the outcome of an outbreak compared to a baseline scenario. Similar to the simple SIR model, implementing shielding measures alone has the potential to reduce the overall burden of an epidemic, lowering the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). In a low-transmission scenario with the same population size, the final epidemic predictions are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite a lower percentage of individuals in the 60 years and older age group, the majority of deaths occur in this demographic, which aligns with estimates from other COVID-19 models and real-world outbreaks. While our simulation focused on the impact of shielding alone, additional measures such as social distancing will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on factors like the number of shields identified and their substitutability, known as αRshields. Demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission rates, and immunity durations also play a role in the population-wide effects of shielding. Populations with a higher number of individuals in older age groups may benefit more from shielding. Although there are fewer recovered individuals aged 20 to 60 to draw from, the potential benefits of shielding remain significant.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei

Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. It is projected that without any interventions, more than 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020, while implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths worldwide. Our research shows that restrictions on mass gatherings and school closures led to significant reductions in infection rates, with reductions of 29.9% and 17.3% respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home measures, resulted in an average reduction in infection rates of 74.4% compared to the baseline. Additionally, we show how our model, DELPHI, can forecast future COVID-19 incidence under different governmental policies and discuss how these analyses were used by Janssen Pharmaceuticals to choose trial locations for their vaccine candidate Ad26.Cov2.S. Our research is available in the e-companion at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases, partial identifiability. The COVID-19 pandemic, as of June 1st, 2022, has resulted in over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths. DELPHI, an epidemiological model developed in late March 2020, extends the classic SEIR model to predict the evolution of the pandemic, taking into account deaths, underdetection of infections, and the impact of government interventions. DELPHI has consistently been included in the CDC's core ensemble forecast, demonstrating its importance in understanding and managing the pandemic.

post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. (2020) explained how the basic reproduction rate R0 and effective reproduction rate Rt play a crucial role in controlling the spread of epidemics. To control the epidemic, Rt must be less than 1, particularly if the initial response was not strong enough. Implementing policies like stay-at-home orders can help mitigate the epidemic, albeit at a significant cost. The timing of these policies is key in reducing the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling shows that starting mitigation efforts earlier can significantly decrease the number of cases and deaths, with some countries potentially avoiding up to 80% of cases. Delays in intervention could result in a much higher death toll, as seen with projected numbers if no measures were taken.

contents: location: hubei, china, hunan, vietnam; time: january 29, 2020
author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Article Title: Modeling the Spread and Control of the COVID-19 Outbreak in Hunan, Vietnam

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Hunan, Vietnam and more than 30 countries in the last two months. This research article focuses on modeling the epidemic dynamics and control strategies of the outbreak in Hunan, Vietnam. Conducted by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various scientific institutions in Vietnam, the study aims to provide insights into the spread and potential containment of COVID-19. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, Vietnam (excluding Hunan), Vietnam (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Vietnam. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Hunan at 0.0643, which is significantly lower than Hunan excluding Hunan (0.1914) and Vietnam excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, the rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Hunan, which declined to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Hunan and Hunan in late March, in Vietnam excluding Hunan in mid March, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. Our model estimates a total of 80,511 infected individuals in Vietnam, with 49,510 in Hunan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Hunan), and 13,322 in other regions of Vietnam (excluding Hunan). It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and come with some level of uncertainty. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hunan until late March. Furthermore, our model can be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic modeling. Author summary: COVID-19 is rapidly spreading in Hunan, Vietnam and more than 30 countries, posing unique challenges due to characteristics like high infectivity during incubation and the delay between actual dynamics and confirmed cases. We have developed a SUQC model to study the dynamics of COVID-19.

Introduction: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has quickly spread in China and more than 30 countries within the last two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

Approach: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to depict the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly account for the effects of control measures. This model provides a more suitable framework for analysis compared to other epidemic models.

Findings: By applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we have analyzed the COVID-19 outbreak in Chengdu, Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), China (excluding Sichuan), and four first-tier cities in China. Our results show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R greater than 1. After January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R less than 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Chengdu estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Sichuan excluding Chengdu (0.1914), and that of China excluding Sichuan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chengdu on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chengdu and Sichuan is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Sichuan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chengdu, 17,679 from Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Sichuan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. Our recommendations include maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Sichuan. This model can be helpful in predicting the epidemic trend and offering guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and over 30 other countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the COVID-19 dynamics and is utilized to predict the epidemic trend in China. This model can also offer guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

pre_context: The provided data is instrumental in assessing the model's performance. In Figure 1B, the blue curve represents the model's fitting result, with blue dots indicating the predicted number of confirmed infections and red dots showing the observed number of confirmed infections. The reported numbers of confirmed cases are based on nucleic acid diagnosis before Feb 12, which transitions to a combination of nucleic acid and clinical diagnosis from Feb 12 to 14, and only the total confirmed numbers are provided from Feb 15 to 21. By comparing with three daily data points of nucleic acid diagnosis, it is evident that the fitted model accurately predicts the observed trend. There is a noticeable discrepancy between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Hubei, largely due to the inclusion of clinical diagnosis by local medical authorities post-Feb 12, which significantly boosts the number of confirmed cases. Despite this, a proportion of the total infected population remains undetected. Utilizing the inferred parameters, long-term projections for the numbers of total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei were plotted in Figure 1A, predicting an end time of 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. An analysis using stage I data of Hubei, which assumes no rigorous quarantine or control measures, using the first 10 daily data points from Jan 20, can also provide valuable insights into predicting the epidemic trend. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The significant difference between predictions based on stage I and II data by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen suggests that measures such as travel restrictions and quarantines have been effective in controlling the epidemic outbreak. With stricter quarantine measures implemented in Hubei and clinical diagnosis changes post-Feb 12, analysis was also conducted on stage III data starting from Feb 13. The estimated quarantine rate in this stage is 0.6185, significantly higher than the 0.3917 estimated in stage II. The total number of infected individuals is estimated to be 49,510, indicating a faster end to the epidemic. Similar analyses were conducted for Hubei province (excluding Hubei), the rest of the country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model's predictions have been highly accurate, showing the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in all regions. Even with stage I data, Beijing showed a reproductive number below 1, reflecting an early and effective response to COVID-19. Hubei had the highest number of infected individuals in China, overwhelming local clinical resources and leading to a low confirmation rate of 0.0643 compared to other regions. The model predicted 26,810 cases in Hubei, highlighting the urgent need for measures to contain the outbreak.
