author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is represented by the equation 1 - g2 δ. A set of ODE equations is established to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and the control by artificial factors (Eq.1). In the model, infected individuals can either go directly to being confirmed (C) or indirectly through quarantine (Q). By eliminating the direct route and simplifying, the model is represented by Eq. 2. Biologically meaningful parameters such as T, w, and R can be defined from the SUQC model to monitor and predict disease trends. Parameter inference is usually based on the number of cumulative confirmed infections (C(t)), the initial values of susceptible individuals (S(0)), and confirmed infections (C(0)). Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China during January 19 and January 29. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . The confirmed number of infections during this period may be more accurate and reflect the true nature of COVID-19, as early numbers were small and fluctuating before January 19 due to strict quarantine measures. The parameter α is challenging to estimate precisely, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 using different methods or data sets. Fortunately, in our model SUQC, the exact value of α is not crucial, as the overall infection ability measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1 is sensitive to parameter optimization and can balance any bias in α with g1. Other parameters and initial values, such as g1, β, U(0), and Q(0), are determined by fitting the daily confirmed infection data to the model. The daily confirmed infections predicted by the model, denoted as ^C=f(g1,β,U0,Q0), are computed using the fourth order Runge-Kutta method. The loss function, err(α,g1,U0,Q0)=||C – ^C||^2, is then optimized using the MATLAB function fmincon to find the parameter values. We experiment with different initial values in optimization and find that the inferred parameters are not heavily influenced by the initial values. We also consider weight loss functions to account for potential bias towards later observations with higher cumulative case numbers.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva are researchers from different institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais, and Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at Federal University of Minas Gerais. They have been studying the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus on global public health and economy.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 epidemic. The ongoing pandemic of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and was first detected in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, leading to severe impacts on the country. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. The crisis has influenced various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, social interactions, environment, and climate. The most effective strategy identified to combat the outbreak involves implementing strict social distancing measures, as highlighted in numerous studies. Many countries are adopting these measures to different degrees of success, although predicting the outcome in such complex societies remains challenging.

COVID-19 is highly contagious, with each case infecting an average of 2.6 people. In simulations, there are initial percentages of infected and immune individuals, with the remaining population being susceptible. author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account involves allowing each data point to follow a specific probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which could be influenced by the mean. The limited data available poses a more significant challenge for modellers. An important factor in explaining the variability in model predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and the model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, underwent testing, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed through lab tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment represents all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, who have or have not sought medical care. It also includes individuals with confirmed tests and those who have been misdiagnosed. Confirmed cases (data) only account for a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions), similar to the iceberg metaphor where the tip of the iceberg above the water surface represents the visible data while the hidden part represents the unknown cases, often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? In model calibration, accurately estimating key parameters like the transmission rate b requires adjusting for the total number of infectious individuals in the model prediction, using the case-infection ratio r to predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different transmission rates b can be estimated and used to determine the basic reproduction number R0, epidemic scale, and peak time. Due to the wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, leading to a wide range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, can make it difficult to uniquely determine model parameters during calibration. Different combinations of parameters that fit the data well can result in very different epidemic predictions. The way nonidentifiability is addressed in calibration greatly impacts the reliability of model predictions. Traditional optimization methods like nonlinear least squares may not effectively handle nonidentifiability, as they may struggle to find the best solution among infinite global minima for the objective function.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies widely, with longer durations typically seen in more severe cases. In our agent-based model, we account for these variations by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Critical cases have a possibility of recovery or death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability of transmission represented by β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. This value was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states and is the default in our model Covasim.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were selected to align with both time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. They aim to yield a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is roughly 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and viral load. The viral load is modeled in two stages: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage, with the high stage lasting either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. This information is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability for an agent on any given day. Fig 2 shows viral load data for a representative sample of individuals.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding based on the severity of the illness. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals as outlined in Table 1. In non-critical cases, recovery is assumed, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2). The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability of transmission denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. The exact value varies depending on factors such as population size and age structure. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was determined through calibrations to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. post_context: .These values are based on relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen for consistency with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. They aim to align closely with the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of β. Individual infectiousness and viral load can vary between people and over time, with viral load highest around or slightly before symptom onset before decreasing. We model two stages of viral load - an early high stage and a longer low stage - with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage and lasting for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load is determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45. Daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability for an agent on a given day. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals is also considered.

The value of β is influenced by the inclusion of realistic network structure, with transmission probabilities set at 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are based on relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen for consistency with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions such as physical distancing. Additionally, individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness can be accounted for by variation in viral load within the model.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Oregon.The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual based on the day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameters. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the situation, with estimated ratios for Seattle detailed in [25]. Studies have conflicting results on whether infectiousness is reduced when the individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be altered as needed for different modeling scenarios or contexts. Some research has suggested much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
